video.title: Numbers - Beau teaches JavaScript
video.description:
Working with numbers in JavaScript including adding, subtracting, multiplying, dividing, modulus, increment, decrement, and compound assignment.

Beau Carnes on Twitter: https://twitter.com/carnesbeau

⭐JavaScript Playlists⭐
▶ES6: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLWKjhJtqVAbljtmmeS0c-CEl2LdE-eR_F
▶JavaScript Basics: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLWKjhJtqVAbk2qRZtWSzCIN38JC_NdhW5
▶Design Patterns: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLWKjhJtqVAbnZtkAI3BqcYxKnfWn_C704
▶Data Structures and Algorithms: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLWKjhJtqVAbkso-IbgiiP48n-O-JQA9PJ
▶Clean Code: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLWKjhJtqVAbkK24EaPurzMq0-kw5U9pJh

-
We're busy people who learn to code, then practice by building projects for nonprofits. Learn Full-stack JavaScript, build a portfolio, and get great references with our open source community.

Join our community at https://freecodecamp.com
Follow us on twitter: https://twitter.com/freecodecamp
Like us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/freecodecamp
Follow Quincy on Quora: https://www.quora.com/Quincy-Larson

topLevelComment.author: John Hutchins
topLevelComment.text: Thank you for the explanation of modulus. How many times does the number on the right, go into the side on the left? (7 goes into 12 one time. the remainder is 5). Another example, 110 % 106 = 4. 106 goes into 110 once, and has 4 left over. THANK YOU for this video, i was having a hard time understanding that.

topLevelComment.author: foobar8
topLevelComment.text:
Beware
0.1 + 0.2 = 0.30000000000000004
2.3 * 3 = 6.8999999999999995
Use decimal.js or alternative if you need to

topLevelComment.text: Hi which code editor you used and any plugin you used for JavaScript console or its a built in feature? - Thank you

replies.author: Beau Carnes
replies.text: Everything I used was on codepen.io. Check the description to a link to the code in the video on codepen.io.

topLevelComment.author: MrVoidfull
topLevelComment.text:
Also, when doing operations, the normal mathematical order of operations apply. And you can use parenthesizes as you would normally do. So 2+2/2 will equal 3,  while (2+2)/2  will equal 2. It's good to keep that in mind, especially when you will have the numbers coming out of variables or functions. 

And great videos Beau, keep them coming!

topLevelComment.author: J
topLevelComment.text: Greats vids, could you make one about Higher order functions "map, reduce,lift". And anything else you might want to add. Thanks!

replies.author: Beau Carnes
replies.text: I have planned some videos on functional programming that will include those. It will be a few weeks before they are released, though. First, I am doing a series on React.
